title: 111_hr4678
content: The Act is titled the "Foreign Manufacturers Legal Accountability Act of 2010" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act titled the "Foreign Manufacturers Legal Accountability Act of 2010" defines the term "applicable agency" for different types of covered products, assigning specific agencies like the FDA, CPSC, EPA, and NHTSA based on product categories. The "Foreign Manufacturers Legal Accountability Act of 2010" assigns specific agencies like the FDA, CPSC, EPA, and NHTSA based on product categories for regulation and oversight. The term "commerce" is defined as trade, traffic, commerce, or transportation between places. The term "covered product" includes drugs, devices, cosmetics, biological products, consumer products, and chemical substances as defined by various Acts. The term "covered product" includes drugs, devices, cosmetics, biological products, consumer products, and chemical substances defined by specific Acts. This encompasses pesticides, motor vehicles, and components intended for these products. "Distribute in commerce" refers to selling, introducing, or holding for sale. The term "foreign manufacturer or producer" excludes those owned or controlled by US individuals with assets exceeding the foreign entity or owning multiple foreign manufacturers. The term "foreign manufacturer or producer" excludes those with assets exceeding the average held by each foreign manufacturer or producer, or affiliated with US operating legal persons certifying responsibility for liability from covered products. The term "foreign manufacturer or producer" excludes those with assets exceeding the average held by each foreign manufacturer or producer, or affiliated with US operating legal persons certifying responsibility for liability from covered products. This includes responsibilities related to testing, assembly, manufacturing, warnings, labeling, inspection, packaging, and being the initial point of contact for safety issues involving covered products. SEC. 3. Registration of agents of foreign manufacturers authorized to accept service of process in the United States. Beginning 180 days after regulations are prescribed, foreign manufacturers of covered products must register a US agent for service of process in regulatory or legal proceedings. Foreign manufacturers of covered products must register a US agent located in a State with a connection to the products and be a permanent resident of the United States. The head of each applicable agency must require a written designation by the manufacturer or producer. Foreign manufacturers of covered products must register a US agent located in a State with a connection to the products and be a permanent resident of the United States. The designation must be signed by an official or employee with authority to appoint an agent, contain legal information, and state its validity. The agent must provide a written acceptance. Foreign manufacturers of covered products must designate a US agent who must be a permanent resident in the US and have the authority to sign for the firm or corporation. The agent's information and acceptance of the designation must be provided in writing. Foreign manufacturers or producers exceeding minimum requirements set by the agency head must comply with paragraph (1). Factors considered include the value and quantity of covered products imported in a calendar year. The Secretary of Commerce, in cooperation with applicable agencies, establishes a registry of agents of foreign manufacturers and certifications. This registry is made available to the public in a searchable format on the Department of Commerce's website. (c) Consent to Jurisdiction.-- A foreign manufacturer or producer of a covered product, by registering an agent, consents to the jurisdiction of State and Federal courts where the agent is located for any judicial proceeding related to the product. This does not apply to actions by foreign plaintiffs for injuries outside the United States. Regulations must be established within one year. The Secretary of Commerce, U.S. Customs and Border Protection Commissioner, and relevant agency heads must create regulations within one year to implement this section. They must also collaborate to establish consistent regulations and minimum requirements for information sharing and system establishment. Upon knowledge of non-compliance with section 2(5)(B) requirements, the agency must notify the Secretary of Commerce to remove certification and inform the person to ensure compliance with section 3. SEC. 4 prohibits the importation of products from manufacturers without registered agents in the US. Enforcement will be overseen by the Secretary of Homeland Security. SEC. 5 requires reporting of defects in covered products in foreign countries. Manufacturers must report safety recalls or campaigns in foreign countries for products similar to those sold in the US to the relevant agency within 5 working days. The head of each agency must prescribe the contents of the notification required by this section. This section will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. STUDY ON REGISTRATION OF AGENTS OF FOREIGN FOOD PRODUCERS AUTHORIZED TO ACCEPT SERVICE OF PROCESS IN THE UNITED STATES. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Commissioner of Food and Drugs will conduct a study on requiring foreign food producers to register a US agent for legal purposes and submit a report to Congress within 1 year. SEC. 7. STUDY ON REGISTRATION OF AGENTS OF FOREIGN MANUFACTURERS AND PRODUCERS OF COMPONENT PARTS WITHIN COVERED PRODUCTS. Within 1 year of this Act, each agency head must complete a study on requiring foreign manufacturers or producers of component parts in products distributed in the US to register agents in the US for legal purposes and submit a report to Congress. SEC. 8. STUDY ON ENFORCEMENT OF US JUDGMENTS REGARDING DEFECTIVE CHINESE DRYWALL. The Comptroller General must conduct a study on enforcing judgments related to defective drywall from China used in US homes from 2004-2007 and submit a report to Congress. SEC. 9. RELATIONSHIP WITH OTHER LAWS. This Act does not impact State authority to establish laws on service of process or personal jurisdiction, unless they conflict with this Act.
